org.mfg.mdb.runtime

Class MDB<T extends IRecord>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.mfg.mdb.runtime.MDB<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The generated record class.
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Demo_02_PriceMDB

    public abstract class MDB<T extends IRecord>
extends java.lang.Object
    Base class for all the MDB generated classes.
    Author:
    arian

      • MDB

        public MDB(java.lang.String tableId,
           java.lang.String tableSignature,
           SessionMode mode,
           java.io.File file,
           java.io.File arrayFile,
           int bufferSize,
           java.lang.String[] columnsName,
           java.lang.Class<?>[] columnsType)
    throws java.io.IOException
        MDB constructor.
        Parameters:
        tableId - An UUID of the table.
        tableSignature - The table signature, is something change in the table definition, the signature changes too.
        mode - The session mode.
        file - The MDB file.
        arrayFile - The MDB file with the array values, or null in case there is not any column of type array.
        bufferSize - The size used for memory buffers and channel buffers.
        columnsName - the columns names.
        columnsType - The columns type.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If there is any problem accessing the file. If there is any problem reading the MDB file.

    • Method Detail

      • getFile

        public java.io.File getFile()
        Get the file associated to this MDB instance.
        Returns:
        The file.

      • getArrayFile

        public java.io.File getArrayFile()
        Get the file associated to this MDB instance. This file contains the data of the columns of type array. In case there is not any column with an array type this method returns null.
        Returns:
        The array file or null if this MDB schema does not contain arrays.

      • thread_randomCursor

        public IRandomCursor<T> thread_randomCursor()
                                     throws java.io.IOException

        Get the random access cursor attached to the current thread. You can use this if you want to reuse the same random cursor. Reuse a cursor is a good idea. Important, this is a deferred cursor, so it is closed automatically at the end of the session, please do not close this cursor yourself, if you want to release the resources associated to a thread, then use the method thread_forget().

        This method is specially helpful to implement the models of visualization components like charts, because usually the graphical toolkits like Swing and SWT use a unique thread to paint, so the models can reuse the same cursors to query the database.

        Returns:
        Random access cursor
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If there is any problem accessing the file.
        See Also:
        MDBSession.defer(ICursor), select(ISeqCursor, long, long), select_sparse(IRandomCursor, ISeqCursor, long, long, int), record(IRandomCursor, long), first(IRandomCursor), last(IRandomCursor)

      • thread_cursor

        public ISeqCursor<T> thread_cursor()
                            throws java.io.IOException

        Get the sequential cursor attached to the current thread. You can use this method if you want to reuse the same cursor. Reuse a cursor is a good idea, just call the ISeqCursor.reset(long, long) method to restart the cursor in a new range. Important, this is a deferred cursor, so it is closed automatically at the end of the session, please do not close this cursor yourself, if you want to release the resources associated to a thread, then use the method thread_forget(). Let's see an example of how to use this method: 

         SomeMDB mdb = ...;
 long start = ...;
 long stop = ...;
 
 Cursor cursor = mdb.cursor_thread();
 
 cursor.reset(start, stop);
 
 while (cursor.next()) {
        doSomething(cursor);
 }

        This method is specially helpful to implement the models of visualization components like charts, because usually the the graphical toolkits like Swing and SWT use a unique thread to paint, so the models can reuse the same cursors to query the database.

        Returns:
        Sequential cursor
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If there is any problem accessing the file.
        See Also:
        MDBSession.defer(ICursor), ISeqCursor.reset(long, long), thread_forget()

      • thread_forget

        public void thread_forget()
                   throws java.io.IOException

        Close and remove the thread cursors. These cursors are the same of the methods thread_cursor() and thread_randomCursor(), see the javadoc of those methods for more detail.

        Reuse the same cursor is a good idea, but it is not a fixed rule, if you are running a session for a long period of time but you need to read the files from time to time, then it is a better idea to close the cursors and make them available to the garbage collector, specially if the application handles a lot of MDB files.

        Important, this does not mean that you cannot use the thread cursors again, you can, but the next time a new cursor is created.

        Take a look to this method: MDBSession.disconnect(MDB). It has a very similar logic, if you are considering to use this method, probably "disconnect" the file from the session is even a better choice.

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If there is any problem accessing the file.
        See Also:
        MDBSession.disconnect(MDB)

      • deleteFiles

        public abstract boolean deleteFiles()
        Delete the associated files. Remember to close the cursors before to perform this operation. If this MDB instance was created with a session, do not call this method, else the MDBSession.closeAndDelete() method.
        Returns:
        true if all files was deleted.

      • select

        public T[] select(ISeqCursor<T> cur,
                  long start,
                  long stop)
           throws java.io.IOException

        Build an array with all the records in the range from position start to stop.

        Note the retrieved data is stored in an array, it means if you are selecting a big range, you can get a memory overflow error. If you need only to read the data and do not store it in memory, then use a sequential cursor.

        Parameters:
        cur - The cursor used to fetch the data.
        start - Range start position.
        stop - Range stop position.
        Returns:
        The array of records.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If there is any problem accessing the file.

      • select_sparse

        public T[] select_sparse(IRandomCursor<T> randCursor,
                         ISeqCursor<T> seqCur,
                         long start,
                         long stop,
                         int maxLen)
                  throws java.io.IOException

        This is a similar method to select(ISeqCursor, long, long), but instead of retrieve all the data from start to stop it retrieves only a fixed number of records ( maxLen). For example, for a file with 10 records, select_sparse(0, 9, 5) returns 5 records at the positions: 0, 2, 4, 6, 8.

        You can use this method to visualize a big amount of data with certain level of detail. The bigger is maxLen, the bigger is the level of detail.

        Parameters:
        randCursor - The random cursor used to fetch the data.
        seqCur - The sequential cursor used to fetch the data.
        start - Range start position
        stop - Range stop position
        maxLen - Max number of records to include in the result.
        Returns:
        The array with the fixed number of records.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If there is any problem accessing the file.

      • getOpenCursorCount

        public abstract int getOpenCursorCount()
        The number of opened cursors. You can use this to "debug" your programs.
        Returns:
        The number of cursors.

      • getRecentRecordsBuffer

        public abstract T[] getRecentRecordsBuffer()

      • list

        public MDBList<T> list(IRandomCursor<T> cursor)

        Create a list using a random cursor and the appender. The data is read by demand.

        We provide this method because the Java List API is well known by all Java developers, however we recommend to use the "native" API provided by MDB: cursors and appenders.

        Parameters:
        cursor - The cursor to fetch the data.
        Returns:
        The list.

      • validate

        public void validate(int max,
                     IValidatorListener<T> listener,
                     IValidator<T>... validators)
              throws java.io.IOException
        Run an array of validators.
        Parameters:
        max - the maximum number of errors.
        listener - The validation listener.
        validators - The array of validators. Default validators are generated together with the MDB classes, see for constants like *_VALIDATOR.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If there is any problem accessing the file.
